You know, Laura, is it really just a question of having a federal statute that deals with discrimination against gays and lesbians in the same way that they are statutes dealing with discrimination among other groups?
Of course not, just because of what Jeff just pointed out.
You know, there's attitude and minds that have to be change.
And that will happen.

Now, I think the attitudes are changing.
They're changing slowly.
The fact that we can even have laws on the books that back civil unions, the fact that, you know, folks are lobbying for this.

Want to move on to a topic about civil rights in the classic sense of African-Americans striving for civil rights.
And yesterday, former President Clinton joined President George W.
Bush and others to break ground at the memorial honoring Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. It's on the mall.
It's going to be a very visible memorial and an expensive one.
Here is what President Bush had to say.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: The King Memorial will span a piece of ground between the Jefferson and Lincoln Memorials.
And by its presence in this place, it will unite the man who declared the promise of America and defended the promise of America with the man who redeemed the promise of America.
(Soundbite of applause)
Partners in the struggle like Andrew Young attended, and so did celebrities, including Oprah Winfrey.
And so with this memorial, we ensure that the very soul of Martin Luther King, Jr. shall be inscribed in our hearts forever.
So as we break ground on this memorial today, we participate in an act of love, as well as a great civic ritual - one that powerfully connects us to the river of American history.
Jeff, Dr. King is the first African-American civilian to be honored with a place at the National Mall.
Is it really important to note where it is and for there to be this kind of visibility?
You know, I think it's as important as the memorial itself.
I think that there's always kind of both an exoteric kind of reason and an esoteric kind of meaning behind it.
I like memorials.
I think it's fabulous, but I also think it's great - I think it's great to commemorate people and the ideas.

In 1995, I traveled to Africa, toured at the northern corner - particularly Egypt - and was thankful that those people of African descent left such a great legacy to commemorate not only the zenith of Africa's civilization, but also one of the world's greatest civilization.
Memorials are important.

However, I can't help but to wonder if you dangled $65 million in front of Dr. King - which is the cost of this memorial so far, what's been raised - not the King kids, now, but Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. himself - if he would wanted to go to a marble or granite or something that bore his name, or would he want that much money and that many resources to go toward an effort to alleviate some of society's ills?
That's a big question.

And Laura, you know, there - from what I understand, this memorial is mainly funded by big companies and, perhaps, some foundations, some wealthy individuals like some film directors - and not so much to grassroots fund raising.
Does that make a difference in this in any way?
I don't think so.
I think it - what it does is it tells you where it's easiest to get - well, you know, in many ways I see is blood money.

These, you know, major corporations and entities want to slap their names on a project like this because it's, frankly, a much easier way to say for a racial justice and equality than it is to actually do anything about their own policies and practices.
And it's a lot easier to raise money from big institutions like this than it is on a grassroots level.
But I think the proof in the pudding will be on who comes to this memorial and who, sort of, takes this memorial into their hearts the way Jeff did when he was visiting Africa.
And I think that it is going to be pretty much the grassroots.
I guess my general reaction would be, though, you know, it took 40 years from the - more than 40 years from the march in Washington for us to get to this point in time.
That tells you a lot about how far we still have to go in terms of racial justice and in terms of filling the King's legacy in this country.
Michael, when it comes to commemorating or upholding, preserving African-American history, there are a lot of efforts running concurrently.
You've got African-American museums, African museums, slavery museums, you know...
The King Center in Atlanta.

Are we seeing a renaissance, or are we seeing people spreading efforts to thin?
